response:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: You can create an iterator for your HColumn<ColName, ColValue> list by creating a wrapper class that implements the Iterator interface. In this wrapper class, you can store the current position in the list and implement the next() and hasNext() methods to return the corresponding ColValue from each HColumn.

Here's an example implementation:
```java
import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.Iterator;
import java.util.List;

public class HColumnIterator implements Iterator<ColValue> {
    private List<HColumn<ColName, ColValue>> columns;
    private int currentPosition;

    public HColumnIterator(List<HColumn<ColName, ColValue>> columns) {
        this.columns = columns;
        this.currentPosition = 0;
    }

    @Override
    public boolean hasNext() {
        return currentPosition < columns.size();
    }

    @Override
    public ColValue next() {
        if (!hasNext()) {
            throw new NoSuchElementException();
        }

        currentPosition++;
        return columns.get(currentPosition - 1).getValue();
    }
}
```
You can then use this iterator by creating an instance of the HColumnIterator class and calling its next() method to retrieve the ColValue from each HColumn.

<<<explanation>>>: By creating a wrapper class that implements the Iterator interface, you can easily create an iterator for your HColumn<ColName, ColValue> list and retrieve the corresponding ColValue from each HColumn in an efficient manner.
